choices.text: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry molars
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson molars
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry incisors
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors

questions.text: Which of the following constitutes Hutchinson's triad? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors

 

Hutchinson's triad refers to:

 

  1. Interstitial keratitis
  2. 8th nerve deafness
  3. Hutchinson incisors

 

Commonly seen in late congenital syphilis.

 

 

Features of Hutchinson Teeth:

 

  • Peg-shaped with a crescent-shaped notch
  • Thinning or discoloration of enamel
  • Smaller teeth
  • Widely spaced teeth

 

Mulberry molars:

 

Mulberry molars (also known as Moon or Fournier molars) are also seen in Congenital Syphilis. They are multicuspid first molars in which the tooth's grinding surface, which is narrower than that at the gingival margin, has many small cusps instead of the usual four well-formed cusps.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry molars: Mulberry molars are also seen in congenital syphilis but are not part of Hutchinson's triad. Mulberry molars (also known as Moon or Fournier molars) are first molars with a narrower grinding surface and multiple small cusps rather than the usual four well-formed cusps.

 

Option B. Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson molars: The correct dental component of Hutchinson's triad is Hutchinson incisors, not molars.

 

Option C. Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry incisors: The term "mulberry incisors" is not accurate; Hutchinson incisors are the correct term, which refers to the characteristic dental deformity in Hutchinson's triad.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hutchinson's triad consists of interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, and Hutchinson incisors, and it is a diagnostic feature of late congenital syphilis.

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with features of respiratory distress and biphasic stridor. There is a history of upper respiratory infection. The radiograph is shown below. Mark the correct diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

 

A child with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor and given radiograph points to a diagnosis of acute laryngotracheobronchitis.

 

 

LARYNGOTRACHEOBRONCHITIS (CROUP)

 

  • Viral infection of glottis & subglottic region
  • Caused by Parainfluenza virus
  • Symptoms: hoarse voice, coryza, mild Tachypnea

 

Treatment –

 

  • Nebulized racemic adrenaline (1:1 mixture of d & I isomers)
  • A single dose of dexamethasone (0.3--0.6 mg/kg, intramuscular) reduces seventy, if given within the first 24 hours.
  • Antibiotics not indicated

 

NOTE -

 

Croup decreases in lying down position and Laryngomalacia increases on lying down

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute epiglottitis: Acute epiglottitis patients, usually 3-6 years of age, present with acute sore throat, high fever, muffled voice, inspiratory stridor, marked dysphagia and drooling. The patient looks toxic and sits in tripod position, sitting upright, leaning forward with chin up. Treatment is IV Ceftriaxone. Lateral neck X-ray reveals thickening of the epiglottis (thumb print sign).

 

 

Option C. Foreign body in glottis: Aspiration of foreign body may result in localized area of wheeze, hyperresonance and reduced air entry. Foreign bodies are removed through a rigid bronchoscope.

 

Option D. Laryngomalacia: Laryngomalacia is M/C cause of congenital laryngeal anomaly.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) is a viral infection of the glottis and subglottic region, often caused by the Parainfluenza virus, and presents with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of some dehydration in a 5-year-old child?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lethargy

 

Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, not some dehydration. In the context of dehydration, it is important to differentiate between signs that indicate mild to moderate (some) dehydration and those that suggest severe dehydration. Lethargy indicates a more serious state of fluid loss that affects the child's overall responsiveness and energy levels, which is not characteristic of mild or moderate dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delayed skin pinch: This sign can occur in both some and severe dehydration. When the skin, typically on the abdomen or arm, is pinched and it returns to its original position slowly, it indicates decreased skin turgor, a common sign of dehydration.

 

Option B. Sunken eyeballs: Sunken eyes can be a symptom of both some and severe dehydration. It is a visible sign that reflects reduced fluid in the body, causing the eyes to appear sunken.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because one of the choices (lethargy) is not a sign of some dehydration but rather severe dehydration.

 

Educational Objective:


Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, whereas delayed skin pinch and sunken eyeballs can be signs of both some and severe dehydration in a 5-year-old child.

questions.text: Which of the following milestones would you generally expect a 3-year-old child to display? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spoon handling

 

By the age of 24 months (2 years), most children develop the ability to use a spoon and feed themselves, which is a key fine motor skill. By the age of 3 years, this skill is typically well established, allowing the child to handle a spoon with greater proficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hopping on one foot: Hopping on one foot is a motor milestone that typically develops around the age of 4 years. Skipping usually comes later, around 5 years.

 

Option C. Copying a triangle: The ability to copy shapes such as a triangle is generally seen around 5 years of age. More complex shapes like a diamond are usually copied around 7 years of age.

 

Option D. Repeats sentences of 10 syllables: A child's ability to repeat longer sentences, including those with 10 syllables, generally develops around 4 to 5 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:


By the age of 3 years, a child is typically expected to handle a spoon and feed themselves, while more complex motor and language skills develop later.

choices.text: It is a mitochondrial storage disorder

questions.text: An 8-year-old child has difficulty walking and getting up from a squatting position. A muscle biopsy was done and is as shown in the image. Which of the following is true about this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Death occurs in 3rd decade

 

The clinical scenario and the muscle biopsy showing fatty replacement of muscle fibers are suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Death in DMD occurs in the late teens and 20s (3rd decade).

 

 

Gower sign:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Previous history of viral prodrome: This option is not correct. DMD is a genetic disorder and does not typically have a history of a viral prodrome.

 

Option C. It is a mitochondrial storage disorder: This option is incorrect. DMD is not a mitochondrial storage disorder; it is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene.

 

Option D. Early treatment has excellent prognosis: While early treatment with corticosteroids can help manage symptoms and slow disease progression, DMD remains a progressive and fatal disease with current treatments. Thus, early treatment does not lead to an "excellent" prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness, and death typically occurs in the late teens to early 20s.

choices.text: Square root of height in feet by weight in grams
Weight in kilograms by cube of height in meters
Mid-upper arm circumference to head circumference ratio
Head circumference to abdominal circumference ratio

questions.text: Ponderal index is defined as: (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Weight in kilograms by cube of height in meters

 

Explanation:

 

The Ponderal Index (PI) is a measure used to assess the leanness or corpulence of a person, especially newborns. It is calculated by dividing the weight in kilograms by the cube of the height in meters. This index helps to distinguish between symmetric and asymmetric growth retardation in infants. A PI of less than 2 indicates asymmetric growth retardation, while a PI of 2 or more suggests normal or symmetric growth retardation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. square root of height in feet by weight in grams - This is not the correct formula for Ponderal Index.

 

Option C. Mid-upper arm circumference to head circumference ratio - This is a different anthropometric measurement.

 

Option D. Head circumference to abdominal circumference ratio - This is another anthropometric ratio used for different assessments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ponderal Index is calculated as weight in kilograms divided by the cube of height in meters, used to assess growth patterns in infants.

questions.text:
What are the recommended actions according to Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines for a baby born with meconium-stained amniotic fluid? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. lntrapartum suction of nose and mouth before delivery of shoulder
  2. lntratracheal suction in case of non-vigorous baby
  3. Gentle suction of nose and mouth in case of vigorous baby
  4. PPV in case of non-vigorous baby after early steps
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4


According to the Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines, the recommended actions for a newborn with meconium-stained amniotic fluid are as follows:

 

4. For a non-vigorous baby (poor muscle tone, weak or absent respiratory effort, or heart rate <100 bpm): The baby should receive positive pressure ventilation (PPV) following initial resuscitation steps. The current guidelines recommend PPV over routine intratracheal suctioning in non-vigorous infants because studies have shown that routine suctioning does not improve outcomes and may delay necessary resuscitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 2, 3, 4: Intrapartum suction of the nose and mouth before delivery of the shoulders and routine intratracheal suctioning are no longer recommended in the current guidelines.

 

Option B. 2, 4: While PPV is recommended for non-vigorous infants, routine intratracheal suctioning is not indicated.

 

Option D. 1, 3, 4: Intrapartum suction is not recommended under the current guidelines.

 

Educational Objective:
 

For a newborn with meconium-stained amniotic fluid, PPV is administered if the baby is non-vigorous after the initial steps of resuscitation.

questions.text: An adolescent girl complains of dropping objects from hands precipitated during morning hours and exams. There is no history of loss of consciousness. One of her cousins has been diagnosed with epilepsy. EEG was suggestive of epileptic spikes. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy


The clinical presentation described is consistent with Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME). JME is characterized by myoclonic jerks, which are sudden, brief, involuntary muscle contractions typically involving both arms. These jerks are most frequent in the morning, often leading to the dropping of objects, as described in this case. The patient maintains consciousness during these episodes, which is typical for JME.

 

Factors supporting the diagnosis:

 

  • Myoclonic jerks: The hallmark seizure type in JME, often occurring shortly after waking up in the morning.
  • Maintained consciousness: The patient remains aware during the myoclonic jerks.
  • Triggers: Seizures can be triggered by stimuli such as sleep deprivation, stress, and photic stimulation (e.g., flashing lights).
  • Genetics: A mutation in the GABRA1 gene is associated with JME.
  • Treatment: Sodium valproate is the drug of choice.
  • Prognosis: Generally good with appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atypical absence: Absence seizures are characterized by brief lapses in consciousness without motor symptoms like dropping objects. Atypical absences last longer than typical ones and have slower onset and resolution.

 

Option C. Choreo-athetoid epilepsy: This condition involves involuntary irregular movements of the face, head, trunk, and extremities, which does not align with the symptoms described in this case.

 

Option D. Centrotemporal spikes: Benign Epilepsy with Centrotemporal Spikes (BECTS), also known as Rolandic epilepsy, involves brief stereotypical partial seizures, typically with facial and oropharyngeal involvement, not consistent with the symptomatology in this case.

 

Educational Objective:


Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME) is characterized by myoclonic jerks, typically occurring in the morning, with preserved consciousness and a good response to sodium valproate.

questions.text:
Consider the following Statements? [INICET NOV 2023]

 

  • Statement 1- Contemplation – A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking
  • Statement 2- Precontemplation – A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to the health
  • Statement 3- Maintenance phase/determination phase – A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then
  • Statement 4- Action phase – A person with obesity says he cant’s do anything as it runs deep in his family
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Statement 1 and 3 are correct

 

1. Contemplation: A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking. This statement correctly aligns with the contemplation phase where an individual acknowledges the problem and begins to think seriously about solving it soon but hasn’t committed to action yet.

 

3. Maintenance phase/determination phase: A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then. This is an accurate description of the maintenance phase, where the individual has made significant changes and is focused on maintaining these changes long-term. The use of "determination phase" here is non-standard; typically, it is just called "maintenance.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Precontemplation: A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to the health. This statement is incorrect for this phase. The precontemplation phase is characterized by a lack of awareness or denial of the problem, not considering changes. The correct description would be not considering the benefits or need for exercise.

 

4. Action phase: A person with obesity says he can't do anything as it runs deep in his family. This statement incorrectly describes the action phase. The action phase involves active modification of behavior. This description instead suggests resignation or justification for inaction, which could fit the precontemplation or contemplation phase but is misaligned with the proactive nature of the action phase.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Behavior change – 6 stages –

 

Precontemplation → Contemplation → Preparation/ Determination → Action/will power → Maintenance → Termination

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom of severe dehydration? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thirsty child.

 

Dehydration in children is classified based on clinical signs into mild (some dehydration) and severe dehydration. The symptoms of severe dehydration are crucial for determining the appropriate treatment and urgency of care.

 

"Thirsty child," is typically associated with some dehydration rather than severe dehydration. A thirsty child is likely still alert and responsive, seeking fluids, which suggests that dehydration is present but not yet severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drowsy child: Indicates severe dehydration where the child’s mental status is altered, often due to inadequate perfusion to the brain.

 

Option B. Skin pinch retracts slowly: This is a reliable sign of severe dehydration and indicates significant fluid loss.

 

Option D. Sunken fontanelle: Especially in infants, a sunken fontanelle is a common and concerning sign of severe dehydration, indicating decreased intracranial pressure due to fluid loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A thirsty child indicates some dehydration, whereas signs like drowsiness, slow skin pinch retraction, and a sunken fontanelle are indicative of severe dehydration.

questions.text: A child in your unit is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). According to the WHO criteria, SAM is defined best by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Weight for height less than -3SD

 

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is best defined as weight for height less than median minus -3SD

 

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by the WHO as any of the following:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weight for age less than -2SD: This defines moderate acute malnutrition (MAM), not severe acute malnutrition (SAM).

 

Option B. Weight for height less than +2SD: This would indicate overnutrition or obesity, not malnutrition.

 

Option C. Weight for age less than +3SD: This is not relevant to malnutrition and could indicate overnutrition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is defined by the WHO as weight-for-height (or length) below -3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards, presence of bilateral pitting edema, or mid-upper arm circumference less than 11.5 cm.

questions.text:
Regarding urinary tract infection (UTI) in children, which of the following is true? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Most common cause of UTI is Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  2. Bowel, bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrence.
  3. Cotrimoxazole is not given.
  4. Micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) is done in children with recurrence of UTI.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

It is true that bowel and bladder dysfunction increase the incidence of recurrence of UTI in children, and that children who experience a recurrence of UTI undergo a micturating cystourethrogram (MCU). 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that bowel and bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrent UTIs in children, and that MCU is performed in cases of recurrent UTI to assess for anatomical and functional abnormalities.

questions.text: A preterm infant in the NICU was observed to have marked nasal flare, distinct xiphoid retractions, minimal intercostal retractions, and inspiratory lag with an audible grunt. What would be the Silverman Anderson score?  ? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8

 

The Silverman-Anderson score is a clinical scoring system used to assess the degree of respiratory distress in neonates, particularly those with hyaline membrane disease (HMD) or other forms of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). The score ranges from 0 to 10, with higher scores indicating more severe respiratory distress.

 

The score is based on five parameters, each scored from 0 to 2:

 

1. Nasal Flaring:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Marked

 

In this case, the infant has marked nasal flaring (score = 2).

 

2. Xiphoid Retractions (Substernal Retractions):

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Distinct

 

The infant has distinct xiphoid retractions (score = 2).

 

3. Intercostal Retractions:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Marked

 

The infant has minimal intercostal retractions (score = 1).

 

4. Chest Movement (Synchrony of Chest and Abdomen):

  • 0: Synchrony
  • 1: Lag on inspiration
  • 2: See-saw movement

 

The infant has inspiratory lag (score = 1).

 

5. Grunting:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Audible with stethoscope
  • 2: Audible without stethoscope

 

The infant has an audible grunt (score = 2).

 

Calculation:

 

  • Nasal Flaring: 2
  • Xiphoid Retractions: 2
  • Intercostal Retractions: 1
  • Chest Movement: 1
  • Grunting: 2

 

Total Score = 2 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 2 = 8

 

The correct Silverman-Anderson score for this infant would be 8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Silverman-Anderson score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in neonates, with a score of 8 indicating significant distress requiring close monitoring and possibly intervention.

choices.text: Cardiomegaly with pulmonary edema
Boot-shaped heart due to right ventricular hypertrophy
Egg-on-a-string appearance due to transposition of the great arteries
Enlarged left atrium with double contour sign

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with cyanosis and episodes of squatting during breathlessness. A chest X-ray is performed, revealing an abnormal heart shape. Based on the findings, which of the following best describes the chest X-ray image?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Boot-shaped heart due to right ventricular hypertrophy

 

Explanation:

 

The chest X-ray image demonstrates a "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart, which is characteristic of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). This distinct appearance is due to right ventricular hypertrophy, which causes the cardiac apex to elevate, giving the heart a boot-like shape. TOF is a congenital heart defect that includes four key features: right ventricular hypertrophy, ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, and an overriding aorta.

 

Key Points from Explanation Hint:

 

"Coeur en sabot" (Boot-shaped Heart): This term refers to the boot-like shape of the heart seen on X-ray due to elevation of the cardiac apex, resulting from right ventricular hypertrophy.

 

Radiographic Features:

 

The hilar areas and lung fields appear relatively clear due to diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries.

 

The aorta is typically large, contributing to the overall radiographic appearance.

 

Clinical Correlation:

 

Children with TOF may present with cyanosis and characteristic symptoms such as squatting during hypoxic episodes, which helps to temporarily increase systemic vascular resistance and improve oxygenation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Cardiomegaly with pulmonary edema: This finding typically shows an enlarged heart with fluid accumulation in the lungs, not seen in TOF.

 

Option C) Egg-on-a-string appearance: This is characteristic of transposition of the great arteries, marked by a narrow superior mediastinum.

 

Option D) Enlarged left atrium with double contour sign: Commonly seen in conditions like mitral stenosis, which are unrelated to TOF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart seen on X-ray is characteristic of Tetralogy of Fallot, resulting from right ventricular hypertrophy. Recognizing this distinctive radiographic feature is essential for diagnosing TOF, a congenital heart condition requiring timely medical or surgical intervention to prevent severe complications.

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of fever, rash, body ache, and throat ache. He has a history of thorn prick injury a week back. What antibiotics would you give empirically to this child? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amoxicilin +clavulanate

 

The symptoms described in this case—fever, rash, sore throat, and body aches—following a thorn prick injury suggest the possibility of scarlet fever caused by Group A Streptococcus (GAS). Scarlet fever typically presents with a diffuse erythematous rash, which may be papular, along with other symptoms such as a sore throat, body aches, and the characteristic "strawberry tongue."

 

Key Points:

 

  • Scarlet Fever and GAS: Scarlet fever is most commonly caused by GAS and is characterized by the production of pyrogenic (erythrogenic) exotoxin, leading to the rash and other systemic symptoms.
  • Empirical Antibiotic Treatment:
    • Amoxicillin + Clavulanate: This combination is a first-line treatment for infections caused by GAS, particularly when there is a concern for beta-lactamase-producing bacteria. Clavulanate inhibits beta-lactamase enzymes, allowing amoxicillin to remain effective against the bacteria.
    • Penicillin or Amoxicillin alone is generally the treatment of choice for scarlet fever, but adding clavulanate broadens the spectrum to cover potential mixed infections.
  • Diagnostic Confirmation: While empirical treatment is initiated, a rapid antigen detection test or throat culture for Streptococcus should be performed to confirm the diagnosis of GAS infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that is typically reserved for more severe infections requiring hospitalization. It is not the first choice for uncomplicated scarlet fever.

 

Option C. Vancomycin. and Option D. Meropenem: These are higher-tier antibiotics reserved for severe or resistant infections, often guided by culture and sensitivity results. They are not typically used as first-line treatment in cases of suspected scarlet fever or mild GAS infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a child presenting with symptoms suggestive of scarlet fever following a thorn prick injury, empirical antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin + clavulanate is appropriate while awaiting diagnostic confirmation of Group A Streptococcus infection.

questions.text: A child presents with generalized edema and was found to have hypercholesterolemia. Urinalysis shows protein 3+ and fat bodies. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nephrotic syndrome

 

The clinical presentation of a child with generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies is highly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome, which is a glomerular disease characterized by heavy proteinuria. The diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome is based on the triad of hypoalbuminemia (≤2.5 g/dL), edema, and hyperlipidemia (cholesterol >200 mg/dL) in addition to proteinuria >3.5 g/24 hr or a urine protein:creatinine ratio >2.

 

Causes of Nephrotic Syndrome:

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Nephritic syndrome: Nephritic syndrome classically presents with tea- or cola-colored urine (hematuria), edema, hypertension, and oliguria.

 

Conditions which present as glomerulonephritis:

 

  • Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  • IgA nephropathy (Option D)
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) nephritis

 

Option C. Goodpasture syndrome: Goodpasture syndrome also referred to as anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease, is an autoimmune disease that affects both the kidneys and lungs by the formation of autoantibodies that attack their basement membranes. Plasmapheresis is recommended in patients with pauci-immune crescentic GN and Goodpasture syndrome.

 

Option D. IgA nephropathy: IgA nephropathy, also known as Berger's disease, is a kidney disorder that occurs when immunoglobulin A (IgA), a protein that helps the body fight infections, settles in the kidneys. This can cause inflammation that, over time, can affect the kidneys' ability to filter waste from the blood. IgA nephropathy is one of the most common glomerulonephritis, a type of kidney disease that affects the glomeruli, the tiny filters within the kidneys that filter waste and excess fluids from the blood.

 

Some common features of IgA nephropathy include:

 

  1. Hematuria: The most common symptom is the presence of blood in the urine (hematuria), which can make the urine appear pink or cola-colored.
  2. Proteinuria: Protein in the urine (proteinuria) may also occur but is typically less significant than in other kidney diseases.
  3. High Blood Pressure: Some individuals may develop high blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies in urinalysis

choices.text: Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

questions.text: A child presents with fever and vesicular lesions on the upper limb and the lower limb. Neck stiffness was present. Similar lesions were present on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. CSF analysis revealed normal glucose levels and elevated lymphocytes and protein. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

 

The clinical vignette and images provided suggest HFMD meningitis.

 

The presence of vesicular lesions on the palms, soles, and oral cavity, as well as images of the lesions, suggest Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD). The presence of neck stiffness, as well as CSF with normal glucose levels, elevated lymphocytes, and protein levels, suggests viral meningitis.

 

Therefore the best answer is - Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

 

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease:

 

Causes:

 

  • Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16 which is a subgroup of enteroviruses.
  • In large outbreaks, other enteroviruses like enterovirus71, coxsackie A viruses 5,6,7,9, 10 and coxsackie B virus 2 and 5 may also cause HFMD.

 

Clinical features: HFMD is often a minor condition.

 

  • The tongue, posterior pharynx, buccal mucosa, palate, lips, etc. may all have vesicular lesions.
  • Lesions that are maculopapular, vesicular, or pustular may appear on the hands, fingers, buttocks, or groin.
  • Compared to the feet, lesions are more frequently found on the hands.
  • These vesicles disappear within a week.
  • Enterovirus 71 infections are more serious and are linked to cardiovascular and neurological symptoms.
  • Complications from coxsackievirus A16 infections might occasionally include shock, encephalitis, acute flaccid paralysis, and myocarditis.
  • A severe variant of HFMD called atypical HFMD is caused by coxsackievirus A6.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • HFMD is usually diagnosed clinically by the characteristic lesions.
  • Viral culture can be done to confirm the presence of enterovirus. Blood, CSF, urine, and mucosal swabs can be cultured.
  • RT-PCR testing to detect the viral genome is more sensitive and specific.
  • PCR testing of CSF in children with meningitis is frequently positive even when the cultures are negative.

 

Treatment:

 

  • No specific antiviral agent is proven to be effective against enteroviruses. Supportive care is the mainstay of treatment.
  • Milrinone is suggested as an effective agent for enterovirus 71 cardiopulmonary disease.
  • Immunoglobulins have been used to manage severe cases but with varying outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis with sepsis: Bacterial meningitis with sepsis is not a likely differential diagnosis for vesicular lesions with this distribution. HSV encephalitis manifests with typical findings of injury to the frontal or parietal cortex or limbic system, including anosmia, memory loss, focal seizures, expressive aphasia, and peculiar behaviour.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex gingivostomatitis and meningoencephalitis: Despite having vesicular lesions, meningoencephalitis and herpes simplex gingivostomatitis show differently clinically. High-grade fever, rapid onset of excruciating mouth pain, and saliva dribbling are the symptoms of HSV gingivostomatitis.

 

Option D. Tuberculous meningitis: Tuberculous meningitis is improbable given the absence of a history of exposure to TB. CSF results in bacterial meningitis often include reduced glucose and raised neutrophils and protein levels. In most cases, CSF results in tuberculous meningitis demonstrate decreased glucose and high amount

 

The majority of the time, CSF results in tuberculous meningitis demonstrate decreased glucose levels, increased lymphocytes, and protein levels.

 

  • Other possible differentials for vesicular lesions include hand-foot-and-mouth disease, varicella (chickenpox), and herpangina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxsackie viral infection can cause Hand-foot-and-mouth disease with associated viral meningitis, characterized by vesicular lesions on the palms, soles, and oral cavity, along with normal glucose and elevated lymphocytes in CSF.

choices.text: Potassium binding resins
Broad spectrum antibiotics

questions.text: A 3-week neonate presents with ambiguous genitalia with Na+ - 127, K+ - 6 meq with a BP of 50/22 mm Hg. Along with IV fluids, what specific management is done? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrocortisone

 

The neonate in this case presents with ambiguous genitalia, hyponatremia (Na+ 127 mEq/L), hyperkalemia (K+ 6 mEq/L), and hypotension (BP 50/22 mm Hg). These findings are suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), most likely due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. CAH is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a deficiency in cortisol production, leading to an overproduction of androgens and a deficiency in aldosterone, which causes salt-wasting and hyperkalemia.

 

The treatment of choice in this situation is hydrocortisone, which replaces the deficient glucocorticoids. Hydrocortisone will help manage the adrenal insufficiency by increasing cortisol levels, thereby normalizing blood pressure, glucose levels, and reducing the overproduction of androgens. In addition to hydrocortisone, mineralocorticoid replacement with fludrocortisone may also be required to address the salt-wasting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spironolactone: This is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist. It is not appropriate in this scenario as it would exacerbate hyperkalemia and does not address the underlying cortisol deficiency.

 

Option B. Potassium binding resins: These are used to treat hyperkalemia by promoting the excretion of potassium in the stool. While they may reduce potassium levels, they do not address the underlying cause of the hyperkalemia, which is the deficiency in cortisol and aldosterone.

 

Option D. Broad spectrum antibiotics: Antibiotics are used to treat infections and are not relevant in managing CAH unless the patient has a concurrent infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrocortisone is the first-line treatment for congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) with 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which presents with ambiguous genitalia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypotension in neonates.

questions.text: At what age does a child attain half-height of the adult height? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20-24 months

 

  • Children attain half of their adult height by the age of 20-24 months.
  • For children under 2 years of age, length is measured with the help of  an infantometer or rigid measuring table. The infant's head is held firmly against a fixed upright headboard, legs are straightened, and feet are at right angles to legs with toes pointing upwards. The length of the baby is measured from a scale set in the measuring table.
  • Measuring the length of a child lying on a mattress or using cloth tapes is inaccurate and not recommended.
  • Height is measured by asking the child to stand upright with heels, buttocks, shoulder blades, and back of the head in contact with a vertical surface such as a wall, height measuring rod, or a stadiometer. The child should look directly forward, and the headpiece is kept firmly over the head to compress the hair.

 

The growth and development of a child between the age of 18 - 24 months can be classified as,

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children typically attain half of their adult height by 20-24 months, a critical milestone in early childhood growth and development.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with sensorineural hearing loss and eye defects presents to the OPD with hematuria. His renal biopsy on light microscopy was normal. Family history reveals the maternal uncle had Gr 5 CKD and is undergoing dialysis. Which of the following would be the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alport syndrome.

 

 

 

A, Alport syndrome (EM), Note the presence of both the characteristic “basket- weave” change (asterisks) and thinning of the GBM (arrows).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Goodpasture syndrome: Goodpasture syndrome is an immune-mediated disease characterised by antibodies against the alpha-3 chain of GBM type IV collagen; it is not hereditary, and light microscopy reveals extracapillary growth with crescents and necrosis.

 

Option C. IgA nephropathy: In IgA nephropathy, light microscopy would demonstrate focal mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis and mesangial widening.

 

Option D. PSGN:  In PSGN, light microscopy would reveal diffuse endocapillary proliferation with concomitant leukocytic infiltration in LM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by hematuria, sensorineural hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities, with characteristic findings on electron microscopy, including a "basket-weave" appearance of the glomerular basement membrane.

questions.text: The given chest X-ray is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tetralogy of Fallot

 

The given chest X-ray is suggestive of the Tetralogy of Fallot. The boot-shaped cardiac silhouette is seen due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex.

 

Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart defect that affects the structure of the heart, specifically the four major components of the heart: the pulmonary valve, the right ventricle, the ventricular septum, and the aortic valve. It is a combination of four heart defects, which are:

 

  1. Pulmonary stenosis - narrowing of the pulmonary valve, which reduces blood flow to the lungs.
  2. Ventricular septal defect - a hole in the wall that separates the right and left ventricles, which allows oxygen-poor and oxygen-rich blood to mix.
  3. Overriding aorta - the aorta is located over the ventricular septal defect, which allows blood to flow from both the left and right ventricles to the body.
  4. Right ventricular hypertrophy - thickening of the right ventricle due to increased workload, which can lead to heart failure.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial septal defect (ASD): This condition typically shows plethoric lung fields and a wide, fixed split of S2. The X-ray findings in the question do not correlate with ASD, as it does not present with a boot-shaped heart.

 

Option C. Ventricular septal defect (VSD): VSD usually shows wide, variable splitting of S2 and plethoric lung fields due to increased pulmonary blood flow. The X-ray findings described do not match VSD.

 

Option D. Ebstein's anomaly: This condition often presents with a box-shaped heart due to maternal lithium intake during pregnancy. The X-ray findings in the question do not show a box-shaped heart, thus not fitting Ebstein's anomaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The boot-shaped heart on a chest X-ray is indicative of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), a congenital heart defect characterized by pulmonary stenosis, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: The patient presented with symptoms of fever, body ache, and joint pain, and was treated with NSAIDs. Subsequently, a few days later, the patient developed brownish pigmentation on the nose. What is the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chikungunya

 

  • The patient's medical history is indicative of a potential diagnosis of Chikungunya (CKG) infection.
  • Chikungunya is a mosquito-borne viral illness presenting with fever, joint pain, and potential rash.

 

 

Fig. Nose pigmentation

 

IMAGE DEPICTING CHIK SIGN

 

  • It can cause skin hyperpigmentation, especially on the nose and cheeks, known as the "Chik sign."
  • The "Chik sign" is distinctive to Chikungunya and is not usually seen with other viral infections.
  • The nose pigmentation may last three to six months post-infection, aiding in clinical and retrospective diagnosis.
  • This pigmentation pattern serves as a clinical marker for Chikungunya infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melasma:

 

Typically presents as symmetric brown patches on the face, especially the cheeks, bridge of the nose, forehead, chin, and above the upper lip as shown in the image below.

 

 

It is often triggered by sun exposure or hormonal changes, such as pregnancy or use of oral contraceptives.

 

Option B. Fixed drug eruption (FDE):

 

  • It is a type of allergic reaction to medications. It presents as well-demarcated, round, or oval patches of redness and swelling that can later become brown.
  • However, FDEs are typically recurrent in the same location when the offending drug is taken again, and the presentation isn't specifically associated with the symptoms described.

 

Option C. Dengue:

 

  • While dengue fever is also a mosquito-borne viral infection leading to symptoms like fever, headache, and joint pains, it does not typically result in brownish pigmentation on the nose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of fever, body ache, and joint pain, followed by the development of brownish pigmentation on the nose, Chikungunya is the probable diagnosis, as it can present with persistent joint pain and hyperpigmentation, particularly in regions where the virus is endemic.

 

 

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 118, Page no 118.11

HARRISONS PRINCIPLES OF INTERNAL MEDICINE 21ST EDITION PAGE 141-142, 1633

questions.text: The hormone that does not play a role in the growth of the fetus is: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Growth hormone.

 

Fetal growth is a complex process regulated by various hormones, but growth hormone does not play a significant role in this process during fetal life. The primary hormones involved in fetal growth include insulin, thyroxine, and glucocorticoids.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Insulin: Insulin is crucial for fetal growth, especially during the third trimester. It plays a key role in promoting the storage of nutrients and the growth of fetal tissues, particularly adipose tissue and muscle.
  • Thyroxine: Fetal production of thyroxine begins around the 12th week of gestation. Thyroxine is vital for the development of the central nervous system and overall growth and differentiation of tissues.
  • Glucocorticoids: Glucocorticoids are essential towards the end of gestation, particularly for the maturation of organs such as the lungs, liver, and gastrointestinal tract. They help prepare the fetus for life outside the womb by stimulating the production of surfactant in the lungs and facilitating the maturation of other critical systems.
  • Growth Hormone: Unlike in postnatal life, where growth hormone is a key regulator of growth, its role in fetal growth is minimal. Fetal growth is largely driven by insulin and other growth factors rather than growth hormone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulin and Option C. Thyroxine: Both are crucial for fetal growth, regulating tissue growth and differentiation, especially in the later stages of pregnancy.

 

Option D. Glucocorticoids: These hormones are essential for the maturation of fetal organs before birth, particularly in the liver, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth hormone does not play a significant role in fetal growth, which is primarily regulated by insulin, thyroxine, and glucocorticoids.

choices.text: Through umbilical vein
Through peripheral vein

questions.text: What is the ideal route of drug delivery during neonatal resuscitation? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Through umbilical vein

 

Explanation:

 

The umbilical vein is the preferred route for drug delivery during neonatal resuscitation. This method is favored because veins in the scalp or extremities can be difficult to access in emergency situations. The umbilical vein provides a reliable and quick access point for administering medications and fluids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intraosseous - Typically used in older children and adults when intravenous access is not possible, but not preferred in neonates during resuscitation.

 

Option C. Through peripheral vein - Peripheral veins are harder to access quickly in a resuscitation scenario involving neonates.

 

Option D. Through umbilical artery - This is not used for drug delivery; it is primarily used for blood gas analysis and monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During neonatal resuscitation, the umbilical vein is the preferred route for drug delivery due to its quick and reliable access.

questions.text: Which of the following Carbapenems has highest risk of causing seizures? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Imipenem

 

  • Imipenem is a Carbapenem that has a maximum risk of causing seizures , hence it is contraindicated in epileptic patients.
  • Imipenem excretion is primarily renal, so dosage adjustments are required to avoid seizures in patients with renal failure.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Meropenem: Meropenem has a lower risk of inducing seizures compared to imipenem, making it a safer alternative for patients with a history of seizures or those at higher risk.

 

Option C. Ertapenem: Ertapenem is also associated with a lower risk of seizures compared to imipenem and is used in various infections but is less effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Acinetobacter species.

 

Option D. Doripenem: Doripenem, like meropenem and ertapenem, has a lower seizure risk compared to imipenem and is used in treating complex bacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Imipenem carries the highest risk of inducing seizures among the carbapenem antibiotics, particularly in patients with renal impairment or a history of epilepsy. Proper dosage adjustments and careful monitoring are essential to minimize this risk.

questions.text: The daughter of a woman who received diethylstilbestrol during her pregnancy is at higher risk for? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clear cell adenocarcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

  • Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic estrogen that was previously prescribed to pregnant women to prevent miscarriages and other pregnancy complications. It was later discovered to be a teratogen and is no longer used.
  • Exposure to DES in utero is known to cause the following conditions:
    • In girls:
      • T-shaped uterus
      • Cockscomb cervix
      • Vaginal and cervical clear cell adenocarcinoma
    • In boys:
      • Micropenis
      • Hypospadias
      • Undescended testes

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of cervical cancer. It arises from the ectocervix, at the squamocolumnar junction. This type of cancer is not specifically associated with DES exposure.

 

Option C. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma arises from the endocervix and is not specifically linked to DES exposure.

 

Option D. Sarcoma botryoides: Sarcoma botryoides is a type of rhabdomyosarcoma that arises from the cervix. It presents as a pinkish polypoidal growth filling up the vagina completely and causes blood-tinged watery discharge. It is not associated with DES exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DES exposure in utero is specifically associated with an increased risk of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina and cervix.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg42

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 - 1 - 3 - 4 - 5

 

The auditory pathway is the sequence of neural structures that sound information travels through from the ear to the brain for processing. The correct sequence from the initial sensory input at the ear to the higher centers of the brain is as follows:

 

2. Spiral ganglion : Contains the cell bodies of the auditory nerve fibers. These neurons receive mechanical sound vibrations converted into electrical signals by the hair cells of the cochlea.

 

1. Cochlear nucleus : The first brainstem nucleus where auditory nerve fibers synapse. This nucleus begins the central processing of auditory information.

 

3. Superior olivary nucleus : Receives inputs from both cochlear nuclei and is involved in binaural cues for sound localization.

 

4. Inferior colliculus : A midbrain nucleus that acts as a major relay and integration point for auditory information.

 

5. Medial geniculate body : Part of the thalamus that acts as the final relay station for auditory information being sent to the auditory cortex in the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA). 
    1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve
    2. Cochlear Nucleus
    3. Superior Olivary nucleus
    4. Lateral lemniscus
    5. Inferior colliculus
    6. Medial geniculate body
    7. Auditory cortex
  • The spiral ganglion situated in Rosenthal's canal contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve which ends in the cochlear nuclei.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for the prophylaxis of motion sickness? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promethazine

 

  • The drug that is used for the prophylaxis of motion sickness is Promethazine.
  • Promethazine is an H1 receptor antagonist with anticholinergic, sedative, and antiemetic properties. It works by blocking the action of histamine in the brain, reducing the symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and dizziness associated with motion sickness.
  • Other drugs used for the treatment of motion sickness include scopolamine (DOC), dimenhydrinate and meclizine, which also have antihistamine properties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cetirizine: Cetirizine is a second-generation antihistamine primarily used for the treatment of allergic rhinitis, hives, and other allergic conditions. It lacks significant sedative and antiemetic effects and is not typically used for motion sickness.

 

Option C. Misolastine: Misolastine is another second-generation antihistamine used for allergic conditions but is not indicated for motion sickness due to its lack of sedative and antiemetic properties.

 

Option D. Loratadine: Loratadine is also a second-generation antihistamine used for allergic conditions. Similar to cetirizine and misolastine, it does not possess the sedative and antiemetic effects required to treat motion sickness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Promethazine is used for the prophylaxis of motion sickness due to its strong antihistamine, anticholinergic, sedative, and antiemetic properties. Second-generation antihistamines like cetirizine, misolastine, and loratadine are not effective for this purpose due to their lack of these properties.

questions.text: A patient was sputum negative for tuberculosis, but chest X-ray was suggestive of tuberculosis. Which is the next step according to RNTCP? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CBNAAT

 

CB-NAAT and Line probe assay are rapid molecular diagnostic techniques used for diagnosis of tuberculosis and also to assess resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin.

 

CB NAAT (Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) provides rapid and accurate diagnosis of TB by detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis and mutations responsible for rifampicin resistance. It can be used for sputum samples as well as samples from extrapulmonary sites.

 

It is mainly used for diagnosis of DR-TB in presumptive DR-TB patients and TB in key populations such as pediatric population, PLHIV and extrapulmonary TB.

 

It is done when smear is negative for TB but chest X-ray is suggestive of tuberculosis and also in cases smear is negative and chest X-ray is not suggestive of TB but there is high index of clinical suspicion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Line probe assay: Line probe assay is another molecular diagnostic test used for detecting resistance to first-line and second-line anti-TB drugs. However, it is not the first choice for initial diagnosis following a negative sputum smear but suggestive chest X-ray.

 

Option C. Liquid culture: Liquid culture is used for confirming TB diagnosis and drug susceptibility testing. It is more time-consuming compared to molecular tests like CBNAAT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with negative sputum smears but chest X-ray findings suggestive of TB, CBNAAT is the recommended next diagnostic step under RNTCP guidelines.

questions.text: A pediatrician is assessing the growth milestones of a child during a routine health visit. The parents are curious about the child’s growth pattern and wonder how close the child is to reaching significant growth milestones. The pediatrician explains that certain ages are critical for reaching specific percentages of adult height. At what age does a child typically attain half of their adult height?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) 18-24 months

 

Explanation:

 

Children generally attain half of their adult height between the ages of 18 to 24 months. Monitoring growth accurately during this period is crucial for assessing normal development and identifying any growth concerns early.

 

Growth Milestone: Children attain half of their adult height by 20-24 months of age.

 

Measuring Techniques:

 

For children under 2 years, length is measured using an infantometer or rigid measuring table. The infant’s head is held against a fixed headboard, legs are straightened, and feet are positioned at right angles with toes pointing upwards. Measurement techniques like using cloth tapes or measuring on a mattress are inaccurate and not recommended.

For children over 2 years, height is measured by asking the child to stand upright with heels, buttocks, shoulder blades, and head against a vertical surface, using a stadiometer or measuring rod. The child should look forward, and the headpiece should be firmly placed over the head to compress the hair.

 

Growth Monitoring:

 

Plotting height and weight on a growth chart helps determine if the child is growing normally for their age and identifies factors affecting growth. Growth charts are routinely used during vaccination visits, minor illness visits, and school health programs.

Regular monitoring of growth helps detect potential growth problems early, such as growth delays, excessive weight gain, or failure to thrive, allowing for timely intervention and management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children typically reach half of their adult height between 18-24 months. Accurate measurement and regular monitoring during this critical period help ensure the child is growing normally, facilitating early detection and management of any growth-related issues.

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV patient presented with a painful lesion, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Kaposi sarcoma

 

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a common malignancy in patients with HIV/AIDS. It is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and typically presents as painless or painful, violaceous (purple) lesions on the skin and mucous membranes, including the oral cavity. The image shows such a lesion on the palate, which is characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma. These lesions are vascular in nature and can vary in color from red to purple, often with a raised or nodular appearance. In HIV patients, Kaposi sarcoma is an AIDS-defining condition and is often seen in those with significant immunosuppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basal cell carcinoma: This type of skin cancer usually occurs in sun-exposed areas of the skin and rarely affects mucous membranes. It typically presents as a pearly or waxy bump, not as multiple purple lesions.

 

Option C. Malignant melanoma: While melanomas can appear as pigmented lesions, they are usually black or brown and rarely present as multiple violaceous lesions in the oral cavity.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of cancer can occur in the oral cavity but usually presents as a non-healing ulcer or a raised, firm, scaly plaque. It does not have the characteristic color and appearance of Kaposi sarcoma lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kaposi sarcoma should be suspected in HIV patients presenting with violaceous lesions on the skin or mucous membranes. It is an AIDS-defining condition associated with HHV-8 infection.

questions.text: All of the following are components of Beck's cognitive theory of depression except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Introjection

 

Introjection is a psychological process where a person unconsciously adopts the ideas or attributes of other people or objects. This is often discussed in psychoanalytic contexts, not cognitive ones.

 

It involves internalizing aspects of others, such as a child internalizing aspects of a lost parent, leading to complex emotional outcomes, which might contribute to the development of depressive feelings.

 

Other Options:

 

Beck's cognitive theory of depression posits that negative thoughts, cognitive distortions, and dysfunctional beliefs are central to the development and maintenance of depression.

 

Option A. Dysfunctional beliefs are ingrained, maladaptive beliefs developed over time, often from childhood experiences, that can trigger depression when activated by stress.

 

Option B. Cognitive distortions are systematic errors in thinking, such as all-or-nothing thinking or overgeneralization, which negatively influence one's perception of reality.

 

Option D. Automatic negative thoughts are recurring negative thoughts that occur spontaneously and contribute to the persistence of depressive symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Introjection is not a component of Beck's cognitive theory of depression; it is associated with psychoanalytic theory, which focuses on internalized feelings towards an object, such as a parent, and is less commonly used in contemporary understanding of depression.

choices.text: The trial investigated NSCLC treatment using a combination of pembrolizumab and chemotherapy.
The trial focused solely on the use of pembrolizumab for treating NSCLC.
The study explored the efficacy of combining nivolumab and chemotherapy for NSCLC.
The trial looked at nivolumab as a treatment option for NSCLC.

questions.text: An oncologist is discussing with a colleague about the latest evidence-based approaches to treating non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The KEYNOTE-189 trial comes up in their conversation. Which of the following accurately describes the focus of the KEYNOTE-189 trial? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The trial investigated NSCLC treatment using a combination of pembrolizumab and chemotherapy.

 

The KEYNOTE trials are a series of clinical studies investigating the use of pembrolizumab, an immune checkpoint inhibitor, in various types of cancer. Pembrolizumab targets the PD-1 receptor, thereby enabling the immune system to better recognize and attack cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The trial focused solely on the use of pembrolizumab for treating NSCLC: This is incorrect. The KEYNOTE-189 trial investigated pembrolizumab in combination with chemotherapy, not as a monotherapy.

 

Option C. The study explored the efficacy of combining nivolumab and chemotherapy for NSCLC: This is incorrect. The KEYNOTE-189 trial did not involve nivolumab; it focused on pembrolizumab in combination with chemotherapy.

 

Option D. The trial looked at nivolumab as a treatment option for NSCLC: This is incorrect. The KEYNOTE-189 trial was centered on pembrolizumab, not nivolumab.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Frontal and maxillary sinuses are larger
Frontal and parietal eminences are larger

questions.text: Which of the following trait is a feature of the female skull? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Frontal and parietal eminences are larger

 

Remember: In general, most features are larger and more prominent in males. However, there are three features which are exceptionally larger or more prominent in females. Just remember these:

 

  • Frontal Eminence is more prominent in females 
  • Parietal Eminence is more prominent in females
  • Orbits are larger in females

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Larger teeth: Incorrect. Male skulls typically have larger teeth compared to females.

 

Option B. Frontal and maxillary sinuses are larger: Incorrect. These sinuses are generally larger in males.

 

Option D. Supratympanic crest is present: Incorrect. This feature is more commonly found in male skulls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

General differences between male and female bones: There are some general features which help to differentiate male and female bones. These are applicable to most bones, hence no need to remember separately for each bone. These are

 

Size: Male bones tend are larger than female bones.

 

Texture: The texture of male bones can be rougher and more rugged due to increased muscle attachment areas.

 

Articular Surface Size: Male bones may have larger articular surfaces compared to females.

 

Bone Markings: Bony markings where muscles and ligaments attach are more prominent in males.

 

So for individual bones, just remember the specific features, instead of general features

questions.text: Which bacterial toxin acts by interfering with EF-2 function? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diphtheria

 

Explanation:

 

Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor 2 (EF-2), blocking its function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium: Produces toxins, but they do not target EF-2.

 

Option C. Bacillus: Associated with different toxins not affecting EF-2.

 

Option D. Vibrio: Known for cholera toxin affecting intestinal secretion, not EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria toxin uniquely targets EF-2, crucial for understanding its mechanism of action in causing disease by inhibiting protein synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a second line anti-tubercular drug? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ethionamide

 

Ethionamide is used as a second-line treatment for tuberculosis (TB), particularly in cases of multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB), when the first-line drugs (like isoniazid, rifampicin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide) are not effective or cannot be used due to resistance or side effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: This is a first-line anti-tubercular drug, widely used in the treatment of both latent and active TB infections.

 

Option C. Acyclovir: Acyclovir is an antiviral medication, primarily used for the treatment of herpes simplex virus infections and not for tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Vancomycin: Vancomycin is an antibiotic used to treat serious bacterial infections caused by gram-positive bacteria, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). It is not used in the treatment of tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethionamide is a second-line anti-tubercular drug used in the management of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), whereas isoniazid is a first-line drug, and acyclovir and vancomycin are not used for tuberculosis treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following regimen is commonly used in the treatment of retinoblastoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vincristine, carboplatin and etoposide

 

Chemotherapy commonly used is a three-drug regimen containing vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide.

 

Treatment of retinoblastoma –

 

 

Other 3 Options: Not commonly used for retinoblastoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most commonly used chemotherapy regimen for retinoblastoma includes vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. This combination is effective in reducing tumor size and facilitating further local treatment options.

choices.text: Complete blood count (CBC)
Bone marrow biopsy

questions.text: A 14-month-old child presents with a history of repeated blood transfusions, with the last transfusion given at 9 months of age. Laboratory evaluation reveals hemoglobin of 6.3 g/dL. Peripheral blood smear shows target cells, as depicted in the image. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following investigations is used for a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Globin gene sequencing

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of severe anemia requiring repeated blood transfusions and the presence of target cells on the blood smear is highly suggestive of thalassemia, an inherited hemoglobin disorder. Thalassemia affects the production of alpha or beta-globin chains, leading to ineffective erythropoiesis and hemolysis.

 

Thalassemia Diagnosis: The severity of the disease correlates with the number of affected globin chain genes. Each individual normally has 4 alpha-chain genes and 2 beta-chain genes. Mutations in these genes can lead to alpha- or beta-thalassemia, with varying severity based on the number of mutated genes.

 

Definitive Diagnosis: The definitive test for diagnosing thalassemia is globin gene sequencing, which identifies specific genetic mutations affecting globin chain production. This test provides accurate diagnosis and helps guide management and genetic counseling.

 

Hemoglobin Levels in Thalassemia:

 

Normal: HbA = 95%, HbA2 = 3.5%, HbF = 1.5%

 

Beta-thalassemia trait: HbA = 90%, HbA2 = 5%, HbF = 5%

 

Beta-thalassemia intermedia: HbA = 45%, HbA2 = 5%, HbF = 50%

 

Screening Tests:

 

Hemoglobin Electrophoresis: Commonly used for newborn screening and identifies abnormal hemoglobin patterns, but it is not definitive for diagnosing specific thalassemia mutations.

 

High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC): Another screening test for detecting abnormal hemoglobin levels but not specific for identifying genetic mutations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Complete blood count (CBC): Provides initial information on anemia but does not confirm the diagnosis of thalassemia.

 

Option B) Hemoglobin electrophoresis: Useful for identifying abnormal hemoglobin patterns but not definitive for thalassemia diagnosis.

 

Option C) Bone marrow biopsy: Not typically used for diagnosing thalassemia; more relevant for other hematological conditions like leukemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Globin gene sequencing is the definitive diagnostic test for thalassemia, providing precise identification of the genetic mutations affecting globin chain production. This test is essential for confirming the diagnosis, guiding treatment, and offering genetic counseling to affected families.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the Pediatrics OPD with the complaints of several episodes of melena. On physical examination, there was eczematous rash over the skin with multiple red pin-point hemorrhagic spots. His Hemogram reveals low platelet count and normal RBC and WBC counts. What is the next best investigation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) WASP gene mutation

 

The clinical symptoms of the patient (recurrent Melena, eczema and red pin-point hemorrhagic spots) are pointing towards the diagnosis of Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome. It occurs due to WASP gene mutation.

 

So Next best step would be to analyze for WASP mutation (Chromosome Xp).

 

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder characterized by –

 

  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Recurrent bleeding (Melena, Epistaxis or Hematemesis)
  • Low Immunity, Recurrent Infections, Eczema
  • Low IgM and high IgA & IgE
  • Normal thymus but reduced T-cells in blood

 

The only treatment for this condition is Bone Marrow Transplantation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-platelet antibodies: While these are relevant in conditions like immune thrombocytopenia (ITP), they are not the primary investigation for Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.

 

Option C. Bone marrow biopsy: This can be used to assess marrow function but is not specific for diagnosing Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.

 

Option D. Electron microscopy: Although useful in some hematological disorders, it is not the first-line diagnostic tool for Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome should be suspected in a pediatric patient with thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent bleeding episodes, and the next best step is to investigate for a WASP gene mutation.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 439-440

questions.text: In Which of the following pathways, cyclooxygenase is involved? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prostaglandin

 

Prostaglandins are derived from arachidonic acid, which is an essential fatty acid found in cell membranes. This process is mediated by Cyclooxygenases called, COX-1 and COX-2

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Kreb's cycle: Kreb's cycle is the terminal pathway for the oxidative catabolism of carbohydrates, amino acids, and fatty acids.

 

Option C. Leukotrienes: Leukotrienes are also produced from arachidonic acid with the help of lipoxygenases.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K is essential for the carboxylation of glutamate residues in certain proteins required for blood clotting. This process does not involve cyclooxygenase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclooxygenase is involved in the prostaglandin synthesis pathway, converting arachidonic acid into prostaglandins, which are key mediators of inflammation, pain, and other physiological responses.

questions.text: What is the most common complication associated with the following abnormality? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Exposure keratopathy

 

  • The given image shows a coloboma of the upper eyelid. The most common complication associated with this condition is exposure keratopathy since the defect leaves the cornea exposed. If left untreated, it can lead to corneal ulceration.

 

CONGENITAL EYELID COLOBOMA

 

  • Can be unilateral or bilateral, involving one or all four lids.
  • The defect may vary from a small marginal notch to a full-thickness absence of the entire eyelid margin involving one-third to half of the eyelid.
  • The upper eyelid is commonly affected.
  • The most common site is the junction between the medial and middle third of the upper eyelid.
  • Eyelid colobomas represent an incomplete form of cryptophthalmos. Cryptophthalmos is a congenital condition in which there is a failure of differentiation of eyelid structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Restricted eye movements: This is not a primary complication of eyelid coloboma. Restricted eye movements are more associated with orbital or extraocular muscle issues.

 

Option C. Diplopia: Diplopia, or double vision, is not a common complication of eyelid coloboma. It usually arises from misalignment of the eyes or neurological conditions.

 

Option D. Amblyopia: Amblyopia, or lazy eye, can occur due to vision deprivation in severe cases of eyelid abnormalities, but it is not the most common complication of eyelid coloboma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eyelid colobomas can be an isolated finding or can be associated with various syndromes mentioned below:

questions.text: Within the framework of Sustainable Development Goal 3, the objective of target 3.1 is to achieve a reduction in the Maternal Mortality Ratio to what specific level (per 1 lakh live birts) by the year 2030? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) <70

 

In Sustainable Development Goal 3, the target 3.1 aims to reduce the Maternal Mortality Ratio by 2030 to <70 per 1 lakh live births.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

SDGs – Targets & Indicators

 

3.1 - By 2030, MMR < 70

3.2 - By 2030, NNMR 12 & U5MR 25

3.3 - By 2030, end epidemics of AIDS, TB, Malaria and NTDs and combat Hepatitis, Water-borne diseases and other CDS.

3.4 - By 2030, reduce by 1/3 premature mortality from NCDs.

3.5 - Strengthen the prevention & treatment of substance abuse.

3.6 - By 2020, halve the global deaths and injuries form RTA.

3.7 - By 2030, universal access to Sexual & Rep – health care services.

3.8 - Achieve Universal health coverage.

3.9 - By 2030, reduce the number of deaths, illnesses form hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.

choices.text: Slowly taper the drug over next 6 months
Continue levetiracetam since a 5-year seizure free interval is needed
Stop levetiracetam and start on a different anti-epileptic
Discontinue the drug as he is seizure free

questions.text: An epileptic patient on levetiracetam has been seizure-free for 2 years. But he develops agitation and anger issues interfering with his day-to-day activities as a result of the drug intake. Which of the following measures is to be taken next? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Slowly taper the drug over next 6 months

 

Levetiracetam is an antiepileptic drug that binds to SV2A on the vesicles and modulates the release of Neurotransmitters. It can cause anger, agitation and mood disturbances as a side effect. In such cases, the drug should be gradually tapered over the next 6 months, but not abruptly stopped as that might lead to rebound seizures.

 

Rationale for Tapering:

 

  • Side Effects: The patient is experiencing significant side effects (agitation and anger) that are interfering with daily activities.
  • Seizure-Free Period: While the patient has been seizure-free for 2 years, abruptly stopping the medication could lead to rebound seizures.
  • Gradual Tapering: Tapering the medication slowly over the next 6 months is a safer approach. It allows the patient's body to adjust and reduces the risk of withdrawal seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Continue levetiracetam since a 5-year seizure-free interval is needed: While a longer seizure-free interval might be ideal, continuing the medication despite significant side effects is not practical. The patient’s quality of life is important, and the side effects need to be addressed.

 

Option C. Stop levetiracetam and start on a different anti-epileptic: Abruptly stopping levetiracetam is not recommended due to the risk of withdrawal seizures. Switching to a different antiepileptic drug (AED) should be done cautiously, and often a cross-tapering strategy is used.

 

Option D. Discontinue the drug as he is seizure-free: Discontinuing the drug abruptly is not advisable, even if the patient has been seizure-free, because it could trigger rebound seizures. A gradual tapering is always preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient on levetiracetam experiences significant psychiatric side effects, the best approach is to slowly taper the medication over several months to prevent rebound seizures and address the side effects.

questions.text: In which disease among the following, Chloride level in sweat is evaluated? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystic fibrosis

 

The chloride level of sweat is evaluated in cystic fibrosis.

 

CYSTIC FIBROSIS

 

  • Autosomal recessive
  • Mutation in chromosome no. 7
  • Primary defect: CFTR gene [Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene on chromosome 7q31.2]
  • Other defects: Chloride channels, Potassium channels, Epithelial sodium channels

 

 

  • Sweat ducts normally absorb sodium from lumen which decreases in CF causing salty sweat.
  • Excessive loss of salt in the sweat is there. Other ducts are obstructed.

 

 

Clinical Features:

 

Hallmark of cystic fibrosis –

 

High sodium and chloride levels Sweat chloride level is >60mEq/L in 2 occasions Airways, pancreas & GIT - Normally sodium uptake is there from luminal fluid but in CF there is increase of sodium and water uptake from lumen causing thick, viscid secretions.

 

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Cystic Fibrosis:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylketonuria: Phenylketonuria occurs due to absence of phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme, leading to phenylketonuria. Diagnosis is made by Ferric chloride test, Guthrie test.

 

Option C. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher disease occurs due to the deficiency of the tissue enzyme glucocerebrosidase that splits glucose from glucosylceramide, resulting in accumulation of the latter in cells of the reticuloendothelial system. Diagnosis is made by measuring glucocerebrosidase levels in leukocytes or skin fibroblasts. Serum chitotriosidase levels are elevated.

 

Option D. Osteogenesis imperfecta: Osteogenesis imperfecta causes defective type-1 collagen. Presents with a triad of blue sclera, Fragile bones, Early deafness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The chloride level in sweat is evaluated to diagnose cystic fibrosis, where elevated levels indicate the disease.

choices.text: Reed Sternberg cells are of B cell origin
Reed Sternberg cells are CD30+ and PAX 5+
Nodular sclerosis HL commonly involves the mediastinum
Commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement about Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring

 

Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) is characterized by the presence of Reed Sternberg cells, which are of B cell origin. These cells typically express CD30 and PAX 5 markers. The nodular sclerosis subtype of HL often involves the mediastinum, where Reed Sternberg cells are referred to as lacunar cells due to their unique appearance in this subtype. However, the statement that the commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring is incorrect. The Waldeyer ring is more commonly involved in non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). HL typically affects the cervical, mediastinal, axillary, and inguinal lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reed Sternberg cells are of B cell origin: Correct. Reed Sternberg cells, the hallmark of Hodgkin lymphoma, originate from B cells.

 

Option B. Reed Sternberg cells are CD30+ and PAX 5+: Correct. Reed Sternberg cells express CD30 and PAX 5 markers, which are used in diagnosing Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option C. Nodular sclerosis HL commonly involves the mediastinum: Correct. The nodular sclerosis subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma frequently involves the mediastinum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hodgkin lymphoma typically involves the cervical, mediastinal, axillary, and inguinal lymph nodes. The involvement of the Waldeyer ring is more characteristic of non-Hodgkin lymphoma

choices.text: Amoxicillin
Fluconazole
Metronidazole

questions.text: A 25-year-old female came with complaints of greenish discharge per vagina and on examination she had a strawberry cervix. Which of the following is the treatment for her? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metronidazole

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of greenish-yellow discharge and a strawberry cervix is characteristic of trichomoniasis. Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. The diagnostic feature of trichomoniasis includes the presence of motile flagellate organisms on a wet mount microscopy.

 

  • Characteristic findings:
    • Colour of discharge: Greenish yellow
    • On examination: Strawberry cervix and vagina
    • pH: >5
    • Diagnosis (Wet mount): Motile flagellate organism

 

Treatment:

 

  • The recommended treatment for trichomoniasis is metronidazole. It can be administered as a single dose of 2g or 200mg TDS for 7 days.

 

Other options:
