Option A. Doxycycline: This antibiotic is used to treat various bacterial infections, including some sexually transmitted infections, but it is not the treatment of choice for trichomoniasis.

 

Option B. Amoxicillin: This antibiotic is used for bacterial infections but is not effective against trichomoniasis.

 

Option C. Fluconazole: This antifungal medication is used to treat candidiasis, not trichomoniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strawberry cervix and greenish-yellow vaginal discharge are characteristic of trichomoniasis, which is treated with metronidazole.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Strawberry cervix and vagina are characteristic of Trichomoniasis

 

Ref: Page no 164, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Serum calcium level
Serum potassium level
Serum bilirubin level

questions.text: A newborn infant of a diabetic mother is being monitored in the neonatal unit due to the increased risk of complications associated with maternal diabetes. The infant appears irritable, has poor feeding, and initial blood glucose is measured at 60 mg/dL. Recognizing that infants born to diabetic mothers are at risk for various metabolic disturbances, the healthcare team decides to perform further evaluations. Which additional investigation is most appropriate for this infant?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Serum calcium level

 

Explanation:

 

Infants born to diabetic mothers are at increased risk for several metabolic disturbances, including hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia. Although this infant’s blood glucose is within an acceptable range, it is important to assess serum calcium levels because hypocalcemia is common in these infants.

 

Risk Factors for Infants of Diabetic Mothers:

 

Infants of diabetic mothers are prone to hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia due to the maternal metabolic influences and adaptations during fetal development.

 

Hypocalcemia in Neonates:

 

Hypocalcemia is defined as low levels of total serum calcium, with a cutoff of less than 8 mg/dL for term infants and less than 7 mg/dL for preterm infants.

 

This condition occurs due to lower levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) in infants of diabetic mothers compared to normal infants after birth. In utero, higher levels of serum ionized calcium may suppress the fetal parathyroid glands, contributing to this condition.

 

Clinical Implications of Hypocalcemia:

 

If left undiagnosed and untreated, hypocalcemia can lead to neurological symptoms, including irritability, poor feeding, seizures, or other neurologic deficits.

 

Evaluation of Infants at Risk:

 

In infants born to diabetic mothers, it is recommended to estimate the serum calcium level to rule out hypocalcemia, even if initial symptoms are subtle or not immediately severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Serum potassium level: Potassium levels are not specifically affected in infants of diabetic mothers, making this less relevant for immediate evaluation.

 

Option C) Serum bilirubin level: Elevated bilirubin is common in newborns but does not directly relate to maternal diabetes and the immediate concerns of hypocalcemia.

 

Option D) Serum creatinine level: Used to assess kidney function, but it is not directly relevant to the primary metabolic risks associated with infants of diabetic mothers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infants born to diabetic mothers should be evaluated for hypocalcemia due to their increased risk, which is influenced by maternal metabolic factors and fetal adaptations. Early detection through serum calcium measurement is essential to prevent neurological complications and ensure proper management.

choices.text: Normal vaginal delivery
Forceps delivery

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the emergency room in the early stage of labor with adequate uterine contractions. On per vaginal examination, a gynecoid pelvis is felt, the membranes are ruptured, and the vertex is felt in the right occipito-posterior position. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal vaginal delivery

 

Explanation:

 

  • Normal vaginal delivery:
    • Assuming the patient has no other complications, such as fetal distress or cephalopelvic disproportion, the given features of right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis (gynecoid) and adequate uterine contractions can be managed by normal vaginal delivery.
    • In 90% of circumstances with a favorable pelvis and strong uterine contractions, without any complications, the occipito-posterior position can undergo the mechanism of normal labor.
    • The patient can be closely monitored for the progress of normal vaginal delivery. However, if complications arise or labor stalls, alternative methods such as vacuum-assisted delivery or forceps delivery may be considered. A cesarean section would only be necessary if there were complications that prevented a safe vaginal delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Vacuum-assisted delivery is generally considered when there is prolonged second stage of labor or fetal distress. In this case, since there are no complications mentioned and the pelvis is favorable, normal vaginal delivery is the preferred option.

 

Option B. Cesarean section: A cesarean section is usually considered when there is cephalopelvic disproportion, fetal distress, or failure to progress in labor. Given the favorable conditions in this scenario, a normal vaginal delivery is feasible.

 

Option D. Forceps delivery: Forceps delivery, like vacuum-assisted delivery, is used in cases of prolonged second stage of labor or when there is a need to expedite delivery. In the absence of such complications, normal vaginal delivery is the appropriate management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis and adequate uterine contractions in a primigravida can be managed by closely monitoring for a normal vaginal delivery, provided there are no complications.

 

Ref: Page 89, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Rosuvastatin should not be combined with which of the following drugs? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Clarithromycin

 

  • Statins are metabolized by CYP3A4 enzyme, which is inhibited by clarithromycin. The plasma levels of statins may rise to high levels if used with clarithromycin, resulting in serious adverse effects like myopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxycodone: Oxycodone is an opioid analgesic used for pain management. It does not interact significantly with rosuvastatin and does not affect its metabolism.

 

Option C. Adalimumab: Adalimumab is a monoclonal antibody used to treat autoimmune conditions. It does not interfere with the metabolism of rosuvastatin and therefore is not associated with increased risk of myopathy when used in combination.

 

Option D. Rivoraxaban: Rivaroxaban is an anticoagulant used to prevent and treat blood clots. It does not interact with the metabolism of rosuvastatin and does not pose a risk of increased myopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs increasing the risk of statin induced myopathy are:

 

  • Amiodarone
  • Gemfibrozil
  • HIV protease inhibitors like saquinavir, ritonavir etc.
  • Clarithromycin
  • Itraconazole

questions.text: Which of the following tests cannot be used to assess nasal mucociliary clearance?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Electron microscopy

 

  • Among the given options, electron microscopy will be the least useful in assessing nasal mucociliary clearance.
  • Electron microscopy -  can detect structural and functional abnormalities of cilia but do not detect any other abnormalities interfering with nasal mucociliary clearance. It is used to visualize the detailed architecture of cilia, which can help identify defects in ciliary structure responsible for impaired mucociliary transport, but it does not measure the actual transport or clearance function.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Saccharin Test: This is a straightforward clinical test where a small amount of saccharin is placed on the nasal mucosa, and the time it takes for the subject to taste the sweetness is measured. This time reflects the mucociliary clearance rate.

 

Option C. Charcoal Powder Method: Involves placing a small amount of charcoal powder in the nose and timing how long it takes for it to appear in the pharynx, similarly assessing the clearance capability of the mucociliary apparatus.

 

Option D. Scintigraphy: This nuclear medicine test uses a small amount of radioactive material to track and record mucociliary transport and clearance, providing both functional and anatomical information about the nasal and sinus mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Test for mucociliary clearance is:
    • Saccharin with or without color test in vivo -   Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance.
    • Radioisotope transport testing in vivo
    • Measuring ciliary activity in vitro
    • Nasal nitric oxide -  Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value
    • Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction
    • Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results.
    • The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.

questions.text: A patient with ascites is found to have SAAG ≥ 1.1. All of the following causes except: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TB peritonitis

 

The Serum-Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG) is calculated to differentiate between ascites caused by portal hypertension (high SAAG ≥ 1.1) and ascites caused by other reasons (low SAAG < 1.1). A SAAG value ≥ 1.1 indicates that the ascites is likely due to issues related to portal hypertension, such as cirrhosis, liver failure, or metastasis to the liver, which can also cause portal hypertension. Tuberculosis peritonitis, however, typically presents with a SAAG lower than 1.1 because it is not associated with portal hypertension but rather with peritoneal inflammation and capillary leak.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cirrhosis: Directly associated with portal hypertension and commonly results in a SAAG ≥ 1.1.

 

Option B. Liver failure: Often leads to portal hypertension, causing a high SAAG.

 

Option C. Metastasis to liver: Can impede hepatic blood flow and increase portal pressure, also leading to a high SAAG.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman on oral contraceptives for the past 6 months presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. What would be the best method of assessing the gestational age of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Crown rump length by USG

 

Explanation:

 

Crown-Rump Length (CRL) by Ultrasound:

 

  • The most accurate method for determining gestational age in the first trimester is by measuring the Crown-Rump Length (CRL) on ultrasound. This method is reliable as it directly measures the embryo or fetus and provides a precise gestational age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adding 280 days to the Last Menstrual Period (LMP):

 

  • This method, known as Naegele’s rule, is commonly used but assumes a regular 28-day menstrual cycle and may not be accurate for women with irregular cycles or those using contraceptives.
  • It is less reliable in this patient who has been on oral contraceptives, which can alter the regularity of menstrual cycles.

 

Option C. Fundus Examination:

 

  • Palpation of the uterine fundus is a physical examination method to estimate gestational age. However, it is less accurate in the first trimester and typically used in the second and third trimesters.

 

Option D. Adding 256 days to the LMP:

 

  • This method is not standard practice and is less commonly used compared to adding 280 days to the LMP.
  • It would be even less reliable in this patient who has been on oral contraceptives.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most accurate method for determining gestational age in the first trimester is the measurement of Crown-Rump Length (CRL) on ultrasound.

 

Ref: Page no 475, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. An abdominal ultrasound reveals the presence of multiple gallstones with no evidence of wall thickening. The bile duct (BD) diameter is measured at 12 mm, and serum bilirubin levels are mildly elevated at 0.8. The patient's alkaline phosphatase levels are significantly elevated at 380, and the gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) levels are raised by 5 times. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MRCP

 

Given the patient's presentation of multiple gallstones, an enlarged bile duct diameter, and elevated liver enzymes, there is a high suspicion of choledocholithiasis (stones in the common bile duct). An MRCP is the most appropriate initial investigation to visualize and confirm the presence of common bile duct stones without subjecting the patient to an invasive procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography): ERCP is an invasive procedure that allows both the visualization and treatment of biliary and pancreatic duct abnormalities. While it can be used to diagnose and treat choledocholithiasis, it is generally reserved for therapeutic interventions after the diagnosis has been established, given the risks associated with the procedure.

 

Option C. Endoscopic ultrasound: This technique can be very sensitive for detecting common bile duct stones and other biliary pathologies. However, in the context of a patient with an enlarged bile duct and elevated liver enzymes suggestive of choledocholithiasis, MRCP would be the preferred initial diagnostic tool.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy: While the patient may ultimately require a cholecystectomy, especially if the gallstones are the cause of her symptoms, it's crucial to first assess and manage any potential common bile duct stones. Directly proceeding to cholecystectomy without addressing potential common bile duct stones could lead to complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, given the patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggesting the presence of common bile duct stones, an MRCP is the most appropriate initial step to visualize the biliary system and confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following TCA cycle intermediate is a part of heme metabolism? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Succinyl CoA

 

TCA cycle is truly amphibolic (both catabolic and anabolic) in nature. Since various compounds enter into or leave from TCA cycle, it is sometimes called as “metabolic traffic circle”.

 

  • Succinyl CoA and Heme Synthesis:
    • Function: Succinyl CoA combines with glycine to form delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA), which is the first step in the synthesis of heme.
    • Enzyme Involved: The enzyme ALA synthase catalyzes this reaction in the mitochondria.
    • Importance: Heme is a vital component of hemoglobin, myoglobin, and various cytochromes involved in electron transport and drug metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha Ketoglutarate:

  • Function: Precursor for the synthesis of glutamate and subsequently other amino acids.
  • Relevance: Not directly involved in heme metabolism.

 

Option B. Fumarate:

  • Function: Intermediate in the TCA cycle, involved in the conversion of fumarate to malate.
  • Relevance: Not directly involved in heme metabolism.

 

Option D. Malate:

  • Function: Intermediate in the TCA cycle, involved in the conversion of malate to oxaloacetate.
  • Relevance: Not directly involved in heme metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important anabolic reactions related with citric acid cycle are:

  1. Oxaloacetate is the precursor of aspartate
  2. Alpha ketoglutarate can be made into glutamate
  3. Succinyl CoA is used for synthesis of heme
  4. Mitochondrial citrate is transported to cytoplasm, where it is cleaved into acetyl CoA, which then is the starting point of fatty acid synthesis.

choices.text: Pernicious anemia
Carcinoid syndrome
Vit B12 Deficiency
Zollinger Ellison syndrome

questions.text: The absence of the structure marked as A will present with all except: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Zollinger Ellison syndrome

 

The eosinophilic appearing cells marked as A are the parietal cells, the absence of which is not associated with Zollinger Ellison Syndrome.

 

 

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is caused by gastrin-secreting tumors, gastrinomas, that are most commonly found in the small intestine or pancreas. Patients often present with duodenal ulcers or chronic diarrhea. Within the stomach, the most remarkable feature is a doubling of oxyntic mucosal thickness due to a fivefold increase in the number of parietal cells It is caused by gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pernicious anemia: This condition is directly related to the absence or dysfunction of parietal cells, leading to a lack of intrinsic factor and B12 deficiency.

 

Option B. Carcinoid syndrome: While not directly related to parietal cells, the presence or absence of parietal cells might influence gastric pH and indirectly affect gastrointestinal symptoms.

 

Option C. Vit B12 Deficiency: B12 deficiency results from a lack of intrinsic factor, which is produced by parietal cells. The absence of parietal cells would lead to B12 deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absence of parietal cells is not associated with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome but can lead to Pernicious anemia and Vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1493

choices.text: No advice as most of drug are not present in breast milk
Give longer half-life drugs
Tell the mother to feed when it is least efficacious
To feed just before the next dose, when the plasma concentration of the drug would be the least

questions.text: What advice do you give to a mother who is using medications during lactation? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. To feed just before the next dose, when the plasma concentration of the drug would be the least

 

When administering medications to a lactating mother, the timing of breast feeding is very important. It is advised to feed the baby just before the intake of the drug, as at that time the plasma concentration of the drug would be least. Then after feeding the drug is taken.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No advice as most of the drug are not present in breast milk: This is incorrect. Many drugs can pass into breast milk to varying degrees. Therefore, careful consideration and advice are needed to minimize infant exposure.

 

Option B. Give longer half-life drugs: This is not a general recommendation. Drugs with longer half-lives stay in the body longer and can potentially accumulate in the breast milk, increasing exposure to the infant.

 

Option C. Tell the mother to feed when it is least efficacious: This advice is not clear or practical. The key is to time breastfeeding relative to the dosing schedule to minimize drug transfer to the breast milk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best advice for a lactating mother using medications is to breastfeed just before taking her next dose of medication. This practice ensures that the drug's plasma concentration is at its lowest during breastfeeding, thereby reducing the amount of drug that passes into the breast milk and minimizing exposure to the infant.

questions.text: I-125 labelled albumin is used for measurement of: (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasma volume

 

Albumin iodinated I-125 serum is a radiopharmaceutical diagnostic agent indicated for use in the determination of total blood and plasma volume.

 

The use of I-125 labeled albumin for the measurement of interstitial fluid volume, intracellular fluid volume or extracellular fluid volume is not common.

 

Other tracers, such as inulin or sucrose, are more commonly used for measuring extracellular or interstitial fluid volume, while radiolabeled water or radiolabeled potassium chloride can be used for measuring total body water and intracellular fluid volume.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Interstitial fluid volume: Incorrect. Interstitial fluid volume is typically measured using other tracers such as inulin or thiosulfate.

 

Option C. ICF (Intracellular Fluid): Incorrect. Intracellular fluid volume is not measured using I-125 labelled albumin. Methods like radiolabeled potassium or total body water (using deuterium or tritium) are used for ICF estimation.

 

Option D. ECF (Extracellular Fluid): Incorrect. Extracellular fluid volume is generally measured using tracers like inulin, which distribute throughout the extracellular compartment but do not enter cells.

 

Educational objective

 

I-125 labelled albumin is specifically used to measure plasma volume. It remains confined to the vascular compartment, making it an effective tracer for determining the volume of plasma within the circulatory system

choices.text: Hemophilus alters penicillin binding protein sites, hence resistant to ampicillin
Easier to administer IV ceftriaxone than IV ampicillin
Cotrimoxazole is the drug of choice, but patient is allergic to sulfa drugs
Hemophilus produces beta lactamase, hence resistant to ampicillin

questions.text: A 14-month-old boy was diagnosed with Hemophilus influenza meningitis. The initial treatment plan was to start on ampicillin but later was shifted to ceftriaxone. What could be the probable reason? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hemophilus produces beta lactamase, hence resistant to ampicillin  

 

Hemophilus influenzae, particularly some strains, can produce beta-lactamase, an enzyme that breaks down the beta-lactam ring found in penicillins (like ampicillin) and some other antibiotics. This enzymatic activity renders these bacteria resistant to the effects of these antibiotics. Due to the increasing prevalence of beta-lactamase-producing H. influenzae, the use of ampicillin alone is often not recommended for serious infections like meningitis. Ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, is a preferred choice as it is more resistant to beta-lactamase and has good central nervous system penetration, which is essential for the treatment of meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemophilus alters penicillin-binding protein sites, hence resistant to ampicillin: While changes in penicillin-binding proteins can confer resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics, this is not the primary mechanism of resistance in H. influenzae. The major concern is beta-lactamase production.

 

Option B. Easier to administer IV ceftriaxone than IV ampicillin: While the ease of administration might be a consideration in some cases (ceftriaxone can be given once a day due to its long half-life), the primary concern in this scenario is antibiotic efficacy and resistance patterns, not the convenience of administration.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole is the drug of choice, but the patient is allergic to sulfa drugs: Cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is not the primary drug of choice for H. influenzae meningitis. The first-line treatment is usually a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone or cefotaxime.

 

Therefore, the most probable reason for switching from ampicillin to ceftriaxone in this case is the beta-lactamase production by H. influenzae, making it resistant to ampicillin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary reason for switching from ampicillin to ceftriaxone in the treatment of Hemophilus influenzae meningitis is the production of beta-lactamase by H. influenzae, which renders the bacteria resistant to ampicillin. Ceftriaxone is more resistant to beta-lactamase and provides effective CNS penetration, making it a more suitable choice for treating bacterial meningitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of infection post-solid organ transplantation in an Indian setting? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

CMV is most common infection occurring after transplant. Risk depends on induction agent and seropositivity status. Minimal risk for D-/R-(Donor, recipient negative). Highest risk of reactivation in D-/R+ and patients who received anti-lymphocyte therapy. Prophylaxis is given pre-emptively if periodic CMV-DNA PCR are >500 copies/ml with Valgan/ Foscarnet/Cidofovir. Letermovir has no hepato/nephrotoxicity (Safest)

 

D-/R- patients should receive leucodepleted blood products to minimise transmission of CMV

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. EBV infection occurs in 1-2% of post-transplant patients and responds well to acyclovir prophylaxis

 

Option C. VZV reactivation can occur at any point post-transplant

 

Option D. HSV occurs within 1-month post-transplant in the absence of acyclovir prophylaxis Nephrology/infectious diseases/post-transplant

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most prevalent and clinically significant viral infection in the post-solid organ transplant setting in India, necessitating targeted prophylaxis and monitoring protocols to mitigate its risks.

 

Reference - Critical Care Nephrology /Chapter 95

questions.text: Purkinje cells of cerebellum relay into: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Dentate nucleus

 

Explanation:

 

The cerebellum's purkinje cells relay information to the dentate nucleus, one of the deep cerebellar nuclei.

 

It is the cerebellum's distinguishing cell. It is a large flask-shaped cell. Climbing fibres from the inferior olivary nucleus stimulate it. This cell's main output is inhibitory in nature and is directed at cerebellar nuclei. These are the most important output neurons.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caudate Nucleus: It's one of the structures that make up the basal ganglia in the brain. The caudate nucleus has a long, C-shaped structure and is located laterally in the brain, near the lateral ventricles. It plays roles in various functions like voluntary movement control, learning, memory, and emotion. Purkinje cells do not primarily relay into the caudate nucleus.

 

Option B. Lentiform Nucleus: Another component of the basal ganglia, the lentiform nucleus is located deep within the brain and is laterally placed in relation to the thalamus. The lentiform nucleus is made up of two structures: the putamen and the globus pallidus. It's involved in movement regulation and other functions. Purkinje cells do not have a direct relay into the lentiform nucleus.

 

Option D. Red Nucleus: Found in the midbrain, the red nucleus has a reddish hue due to its rich blood supply and the presence of iron. It plays a role in motor coordination, particularly in the coordination of limb movements. While the red nucleus does receive input from the cerebellum, the primary relay from Purkinje cells is to the deep cerebellar nuclei, not directly to the red nucleus. The dentate nucleus, in turn, can send projections to the red nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dentate Nucleus is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei and is situated within the white matter of the cerebellum. The dentate nucleus is the largest of the deep cerebellar nuclei and plays a role in the planning, initiation, and control of voluntary movements.

 

Purkinje cells in the cerebellar cortex send inhibitory projections to the deep cerebellar nuclei, including the dentate nucleus. This is the main output pathway for the cerebellar cortex.
